reason: Setting `ndarray.shape` in-place is considered error-prone and will fail if a copy is required. `ndarray.reshape` is preferred for reshaping arrays as it avoids ambiguity and creates a copy if needed.

Setting `ndarray.dtype` directly modifies the data type of an array without changing the underlying memory structure, which can lead to unexpected behavior. Using `ndarray.view` or `ndarray.astype` provides safer alternatives.
Setting `arr.strides` directly is discouraged due to safety concerns. Using `numpy.lib.stride_tricks.as_strided` is safer and avoids issues with manipulating memory directly.
Clarification of API behavior; `ndarray.T` is functionally equivalent to `transpose()` but may be less explicit for some users. No removal or deprecation is indicated.
This function differs from `numpy.copy` by defaulting to `order='C'` and passing sub-classes through, which allows more flexible handling of array memory layout and subclasses.
To provide a more consistent API by transitioning certain operations from methods to functions.
Unified documentation suggests referring users to the equivalent function `numpy.repeat` for clarity and to promote consistent usage across the NumPy API.
The `numpy.ndarray.put` method was updated to encourage users to use the equivalent standalone function `numpy.put` for consistency and broader compatibility.
Passing booleans as indices to the `kth` parameter was deprecated to ensure consistent behavior with other NumPy APIs and to reduce ambiguity in the type of arguments.
Consolidation of functionality into a more generic global function (numpy.searchsorted), ensuring consistency and reducing redundancy in the API design.
The documentation suggests using `numpy.nonzero` function, emphasizing it for full documentation, potentially indicating a preference for the function over the `ndarray.nonzero` method.

The behavior was changed to return a read-only view instead of a copy for performance and memory optimization. A read-only restriction was introduced to ensure data consistency, which may be removed in future versions.
Standardization to encourage usage of the equivalent function `numpy.amin` for clarity and consistency across the API.

The documentation indicates that 'numpy.ndarray.max' method is equivalent to the 'numpy.amax' function, suggesting a preference for the latter for comprehensive details. There is no explicit information about deprecation or removal.
Encourage users to use the equivalent function `numpy.around` for better consistency across the library.
Streamline API behavior by recommending the equivalent standalone function for consistent usage across the NumPy system.
To clearly differentiate between the method (`ndarray.var`) and the function (`numpy.var`), allowing users to refer directly to the equivalent function.
Moved functionality to a function-level API for consistency across packages and easier usage.
The equivalent standalone function `numpy.prod` is preferred for clarity, while `numpy.ndarray.prod` retains its method-based approach for array objects.
The documentation suggests users refer to `ndarray.T`, indicating that `numpy.generic.T` is identical to its array counterpart and may have shifted focus toward promoting `ndarray` for uniformity.
The scalar method `generic.squeeze` is identical to the corresponding array attribute `ndarray.squeeze`, encouraging developers to use the array attribute for consistency and clarity.
Promoting the use of `numpy.ndarray` over `numpy.matrix` as `numpy.matrix` is generally discouraged in modern NumPy applications.

NumPy recommends using `numpy.linalg.inv` for matrix inversion. The use of `numpy.matrix` and its related APIs is discouraged due to limitations such as lack of support for general N-dimensional arrays.

removed_in: unspecified (may be removed in the future)
reason: It is no longer recommended to use the numpy.matrix class. Regular arrays (ndarray) provide similar functionality and greater flexibility while being the preferred method for handling linear algebra operations in NumPy.
Generalization for N-d arrays was introduced through `numpy.block`, which offers broader functionality and greater flexibility compared to `numpy.bmat`.
The `chararray` class is primarily provided for backward compatibility with numarray and is not recommended for new code. Standard NumPy arrays are more versatile and efficient for string operations.

The chararray class exists mainly for backward compatibility with Numarray. Starting from NumPy 1.4, users are encouraged to use arrays of dtype object_, bytes_, or str_ instead for creating arrays of strings, along with the free functions in the numpy.char module for efficient vectorized string operations.
This API, previously documented under `masked_array`, is now an alias of `MaskedArray`, to consolidate naming consistency within the `numpy.ma` module.
To align functionality between masked arrays and ndarrays.
To ensure a consistent return value of boolean arrays, `getmaskarray` was introduced as a more predictable alternative for cases where a full array of booleans is required.
The `isarray` function is an alias for `isMaskedArray`, and hence may cause redundancy or confusion with other similar function names.
The `isin` function is recommended for new code because it is more versatile and preserves the shape of the input array.
Standardizing behavior across NumPy APIs to align masked array operations with ndarray operations.
Consolidation of functionality into the `MaskedArray` class for consistency and alignment with object-oriented design.
A masked array does not own its data and therefore cannot safely be resized in place. Implementing this method safely is difficult, and it might be deprecated in future releases.
Align functionality and documentation with its equivalent function in the main NumPy module for consistency.
Simplification and alignment with the core NumPy API.

Passing an axis where axis > a.ndim is treated as axis == a.ndim, and passing axis < -a.ndim - 1 is treated as axis == 0. This behavior was deprecated to prevent ambiguity and improve consistency in API usage.
The `mask_cols` function was streamlined to align with the more general and versatile `mask_rowcols`, which provides masking capability for both rows and columns with enhanced flexibility.
Improved clarity and flexibility by standardizing masking operations under `masked_where`.
Modification to provide a shortcut for masking values outside a specified interval using existing functionality.
compress_cols is equivalent to np.ma.compress_rowcols with axis=1. This unification simplifies the API structure.
The 'bias' and 'ddof' parameters were accepted but had no effect on the return values of the function, making them redundant. They were deprecated for clarity and backward compatibility.
Enhanced consistency across APIs by recommending the equivalent function for non-masked arrays.
The function provides specialized behavior for masked arrays, but users are encouraged to utilize the general numpy.cumsum function for broader compatibility.
Unified functionality with `numpy.prod` for consistency across masked arrays and standard ndarrays.
Updated documentation to align with numpy.mean, behavior remains consistent but emphasizes masked entries being ignored and non-finite elements being masked.
Consolidation of array functions under a unified namespace to simplify usage and documentation.
To provide clearer API aliasing and streamline usage.
The new `numpy.polynomial` API is numerically more stable and provides greater functionality compared to the old `numpy.ma.polyfit` API.
Unified functionality with `numpy.clip` to standardize and simplify API usage.
Align functionality with `numpy.around` for unified behavior across similar APIs in NumPy.
Introduced as an equivalent function in the masked array module, ensuring compatibility with masked arrays and aligning functionality with the ndarray version.
The `numpy.ma.amax` function is an alias for `numpy.ma.max`, which provides the same functionality more directly and is the preferred method.
The alias 'amin' for 'min' was clarified for consistency within the NumPy masked array module and the behavior of universal functions.
The function is stated to be equivalent to MaskedArray.put and is referred to that method for details, suggesting a shift in emphasis or preference towards using MaskedArray.put directly.

The top-level `numpy.ma.where` API was likely deprecated to provide consistent behavior across the broader NumPy library, reducing redundancy and encouraging the use of the general `numpy.where` function.
NumPy `around` is an alias for `round` and maintains equivalent behavior. This clarification serves to streamline understanding between the two APIs and their functionalities.
numpy.cumulative_sum was introduced as an Array API-compatible alternative to numpy.cumsum, offering functionality to include an initial value and better compliance with the Array API standard.
Improved compatibility with the Array API standard and enhanced functionality by supporting the `include_initial` parameter, which was not present in numpy.cumprod.
The `numpy.cumulative_prod` interface provides better compatibility with the Array API standard.
Modular arithmetic behavior in integer types and floating-point roundoff differences in summation operations.
Dimension-2 input arrays were deprecated to improve API consistency and encourage the usage of higher-dimensional arrays for cross products.
The scipy implementation is a proper ufunc written in C, and offers significantly better performance than numpy.i0.
The `numpy.true_divide` function is effectively an alias for `numpy.divide`, making the distinction unnecessary and encouraging standardization.

The behavior aligns with Python's modulus operator (`%`) but differs from MATLAB's `rem` function and C's `%` operator for floor division behavior. It aims for consistent mathematical behavior and functional equivalence.
The alias `numpy.conj` is redundant and less explicit compared to `numpy.conjugate`.
The `amax` function is considered an alias for `max` as it provides identical functionality. Aligning it further with `numpy.max` ensures consistency in naming conventions across the NumPy API.
Alias of `numpy.min` to standardize function usage and reduce redundancy.

To provide a consistent approach for calculating square roots of negative reals and complex numbers. The default numpy.sqrt returns NaN for negative reals and a complex array for complex inputs, while numpy.emath.sqrt handles negative reals by returning a complex result.
numpy.true_divide is an alias for numpy.divide, offering clearer naming for true division operations. This change improves code clarity and documentation consistency.
